# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

# Function Definition
```julia
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter for Audi cars
    df_audis = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi", df)
    # Filter for A4 and A4 quattro models
    df_a4s = filter(row -> (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df_audis)
    # Create new column with all values as true
    df_a4s[:audi_a4_type] .= true
    return df_a4s
end
```

# Function Application
```julia
using DataFrames

# Sample data
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

# Apply the function
result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

The `audi_filter` function first filters the dataset for rows with manufacturer "audi" using the `filter` function. It then filters this subset further for models that are either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Finally, it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` and assigns `true` to all values in this column. The resulting DataFrame is returned.

Please note that the above code assumes you are using Julia version 1.6 or later due to the use of the `::DataFrame` type annotation and the chaining of `filter` functions. If you are using an earlier version, you may need to adjust the syntax accordingly.
